metadata.titleEn: HiWATER：Dataset of Hydrometeorological observation network (an observation system of Meteorological elements gradient of Sidaoqiao Superstation, 2017)
metadata.description:
The data set contains data from the meteorological gradient observation system of sidaqiao super station downstream of heihe hydrometeorological observation network from January 1, 2017 to December 31, 2017.The station is located in the four Bridges of dalaihubu town, ejin banner, Inner Mongolia.The latitude and longitude of the observation point are 101.1374e, 42.0012n, and 873m above sea level.Air temperature, relative humidity and wind speed sensors are installed at 5m, 7m, 10m, 15m, 20m and 28m, with a total of 6 layers, facing due north.The wind sensor is installed at 15m, facing due north;The barometer is installed in the waterproof box;Dump-type rain gauge installed at 28m;The four-component radiometer is installed at 10m, facing due south;The two infrared thermometers are installed at 10m, facing due south, and the probe is facing vertically down.The two photosynthetic effective radiometers are installed at a location of 10m, facing due south, with the probes pointing vertically up and down, respectively.Part of the soil sensor is installed at 2m to the south of the tower body, in which the soil heat flow plate (self-calibration formal) (3 pieces) is successively buried at 6cm underground;The average soil temperature sensor TCAV is buried 2cm and 4cm underground.The soil temperature probe is buried at 0cm on the surface and 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 80cm, 120cm, 160cm and 200cm underground.The soil moisture sensors were embedded in the ground at 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 80cm, 120cm, 160cm and 200cm.
The observation items are: wind speed (WS_5m, WS_7m, WS_10m, WS_15m, WS_20m, WS_28m) (unit: m/s), wind direction (WD_15m) (unit: degree), air temperature and humidity (Ta_5m, Ta_7m, Ta_10m, Ta_15m, Ta_20m, Ta_28m and RH_5m, RH_7m, RH_10m, RH_15m, RH_20m, RH_28m) (unit: Celsius, percentage), air pressure (Press) (unit:Hundred mpa), precipitation (Rain) (unit: mm), the radiation of four component (DR, UR, DLR_Cor, ULR_Cor, Rn) (unit: watts per square meter), the surface radiation temperature (IRT_1, IRT_2) (unit: c), up and down the photosynthetic active radiation (PAR_U_up, PAR_U_down) (unit: second micromoles/m2), the average soil temperature (TCAV) (unit: c), soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, Gs_3) (unit:W/m2), soil moisture (Ms_2cm, Ms_4cm, Ms_10cm, Ms_20cm, Ms_40cm, Ms_80cm, Ms_120cm, Ms_160cm, Ms_200cm) (unit: volume water content, percentage), soil temperature (Ts_0cm, Ts_2cm, Ts_4cm, Ts_10cm, Ts_20cm, Ts_40cm, Ts_80cm, Ts_120cm, Ts_160cm, Ts_200cm) (unit: Celsius).
Processing and quality control of observation data :(1) ensure 144 data per day (every 10min). If data is missing, it will be marked by -6999;(2) eliminate the moments with duplicate records;(3) data that is obviously beyond the physical meaning or the range of the instrument is deleted;(4) the part marked by red letter in the data is the data in question;(5) the format of date and time is uniform, and the date and time are in the same column.For example, the time is: 2017-9-10-10:30;(6) the naming rule is: AWS+ site name.
Please refer to Li et al. (2013) for hydrometeorological network or site information, and Liu et al. (2011) for observation data processing.

background: The two-source energy balance (TSEB) model was successfully applied to estimate evaporation (E), transpiration (T), and evapotranspiration (ET) for land covered with vegetation, which has significantly important applications for the terrestrial water cycle and water resource management. One-source evapotranspiration estimation models combine the soil–vegetation components into a single source. However, in real landscape conditions, the surface is heterogeneous and contains a mixture of soil and vegetation having different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. Therefore, one-source models explicitly cannot estimate the surface evapotranspiration accurately because the effect of.

Shuttleworth and Wallace proposed a typical two-source evapotranspiration estimation model in which the energy partition is assumed to occur in both “the above canopy” and “the under soil” cases. Water vapor and heat meet over the reference height in the interior of the canopy. Moreover, the mixed water vapor and heat can only exit through the top of the canopy; the total heat flux is in addition to the fluxes coming from every surface layer. However, the model is complex, having over five resistances that cannot be accurately calculated. In addition, the model includes required parameters and observations that cannot be readily obtained from operational satellite- and ground-based data; therefore, the range of applications of the model is limited.

The TSEB model has undergone several revisions, improving the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, the aerodynamic resistance of the soil surface, the fractional vegetation coverage observed at the radiometer view angle, the distribution of regional-scale near-surface air temperature, and soil and canopy component temperatures. Because the TSEB model only requires the surface energy balance model with a single measurement of land surface temperature, the original model and subsequent refinements have been widely used to estimate E and T under a wide variety of vegetation types, vegetation coverage, climates, and spatial scales. However, most studies have only evaluated the total fluxes or ET (soil plus canopy) in comparison with measurements using the Bowen ratio–energy balance system, the eddy covariance (EC) system, or the large aperture scintillometer.

Accurately estimating surface fluxes in a strongly advective irrigated agricultural area is a particularly challenging task and is even more difficult when the EC flux measurements of H and LE have an incomplete energy balance closure with respect to the available energy Rn−G0. The previous sensitivity studies found that the TSEB model performance is mainly affected by the uncertainty in surface–air temperature difference. Sometimes, this difference is dominant due to the errors in determining the surface soil and vegetation component temperatures from the surface composite radiometric temperature. In this letter, it is shown that there is an overestimation of the component temperatures compared with the observed composite radiometric. This often leads to the most crucial effect on the TSEB model performance. In addition, another factor is the strong advective environment in this region.
research objective: In this letter, the ground-measured soil and canopy component temperatures were used to estimate E, T, and ET, which were better validated with observed ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes, and the ET measurements using an eddy covariance (EC) system.

The objective of this letter is to estimate E, T, and ET using the soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model and to subsequently better validate E, T, and ET using a combination of the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope technique and EC measurements.
challenges: However, the current composite temperature separation approaches are limited in their effectiveness in arid regions. Moreover, E and T are difficult to measure on the ground.

Errors in the derived component temperature were primarily caused by image classification errors; these classification errors varied with vegetation abundance. The higher uncertainty of H estimation is not only caused by the uncertainty of the TSEB model but also due to the increased uncertainty of the EC system, which is 18% when the mean H is small in the irrigated farmland. Due to image pixel classification errors, soil pixels were counted as vegetation pixels, which produced an overestimation of the canopy temperature under the developing vegetation abundance. Alternatively, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could have produced the uncertainties in the estimated temperatures. In addition, the estimated uncertainty of the incoming short- and long-wave radiation transmittances through the canopy may be another source of Rn estimation errors.
methods: In this letter, the field observations were obtained from the Daman superstation installed in the central oasis, which is a 40-m boundary layer tower located at 100.3722° E, 38.8555° N and at an elevation of 1556 m. The meteorological parameters were measured every 10 min and included air temperature, wind speed, humidity at 5 m over the ground, four-component radiations (measured at 12 m above the ground using a four-component radiometer), and turbulent fluxes (measured at 4.5 m above the ground using an EC system with a sampling frequency of 10 Hz). The soil heat fluxes were measured using three heat plates located 6 cm under the ground. A Fluke Ti55 thermal infrared camera was manually operated on a 25-m-high platform on a boundary layer tower to measure the thermal radiation of the cropland approximately every 120 min; the observations were collected as thermal images from approximately 07:00 to 19:00 China Standard Time (CST) during the daytime. The ground-based measurement data were applied to partition ET into E and T applying the Craig–Gordon model.

To evaluate the TSEB model accurately, the soil heat flux was using the ground measurement. In addition, the soil and canopy sensible heat fluxes were estimated using the series TSEB model, and their latent heat fluxes were calculated while solving the energy balance equations (1) and (2), respectively. The soil and canopy component temperatures were calculated using the images obtained with the thermal camera. To calculate the component temperatures, the visible and NIR images were classified into soil and canopy pixels using the maximum-likelihood method. Next, the soil and canopy directional brightness temperatures were exacted from the thermal images. Finally, the thermal infrared temperatures were converted to the radiation temperatures using the incoming long-wave radiation from the sky and the soil and canopy emissivities. Next, the simulated radiometric temperatures were validated against the surface radiometric temperatures, which were calculated according to the incoming long-wave radiation observed by the four-component radiometer.
dataset: The experimental area is an artificial oasis that is covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards. Data of day of year (DOY) 170, 173, 176, 192, 195, 231, 252, and 256 were used to determine ET and the ratios of E (E/ET%) and T (T/ET%) to ET during the Multi-Scale Observation Experiment on Evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces, which was part of the Heihe Water Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER-MUSOEXE).
findings: Our results indicated that even under the strongly advective conditions, the TSEB model produced reliable estimates of the E/ET% and T/ET% ratios and of ET. The mean bias and root-mean-square error (RMSE) of E/ET% were 1% and 2%, respectively, and the mean bias and RMSE of T/ET% were −1% and 2%, respectively. In addition, the model exhibited relatively reliable estimates in the latent heat flux, with mean bias and RMSE values of 31 and 61 W·m−2, respectively, compared with the measurements from the EC system. These results demonstrated that a robust soil and vegetation component temperature calculation was crucial for estimating E, T, and ET. Moreover, the separate validation of E/ET% and T/ET% provides a good prospect for TSEB model improvements.

Our results demonstrated that the TSEB model using soil and canopy component radiometric temperatures, which were obtained from a high-precision thermal infrared camera, can be applied in a strongly advection-irrigated agricultural area. Notably, the results illustrated that the latent fluxes of the soil and vegetation components were successfully separated with reasonable accuracy, as assessed using ground-based measurements. The estimated E/ET% and E/ET% values agreed well with the values observed using the stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes technique during the early, middle, and late growing seasons. In addition, the TSEB model produced reliable estimations of Rn, H, and LE; the mean biases of Rn, H, and LE were −18, 5, and 31 W ·m−2, respectively, and the RMSEs of Rn, H, and LE were 29, 19, and 61 W · m−2, respectively. This finding suggests that given accurate soil and vegetation component temperatures, E and T can be accurately separated from ET using the TSEB model.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Verification.Question: Is the use of eddy covariance systems a reliable method for measuring latent heat fluxes in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the primary data collection methods used in observing hydrometeorological variables at a meteorological station?
What challenges might arise in data collection for energy balance models in strongly advective agricultural areas?

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that illustrates long-term observations in an oasis–desert system?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset includes long-term observations from 2012 to 2021 in artificial and natural oasis–desert systems, comprising energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes along with auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of the challenges faced in data collection in arid and semi-arid regions?
Example.Answer: Challenges in data collection in arid and semi-arid regions often include dealing with ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, land desertification, and frequent dust storms, particularly in inland river basins westward along the Silk Road.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the defining features of data processing and quality control in long-term hydrometeorological studies?
Feature Specification.Answer: consistent collection every 10 minutes, handling missing data with specific markers, removing duplicate or physically implausible data, standardizing date and time formats, marking suspect data, station-specific naming conventions

Definition.Question: What are some challenges associated with accurately estimating surface fluxes in arid and semiarid regions?
Definition.Answer: Accurately estimating surface fluxes in arid and semiarid regions can be challenging due to factors like heterogeneous landscapes with mixed soil and vegetation, advective conditions, and incomplete energy balance closure in EC flux measurements. Additionally, image classification errors and uncertainties in component temperatures derived from radiometric measurements can affect the accuracy of models such as the Two-Source Energy Balance (TSEB) model used to estimate evapotranspiration.

Definition.Question: What does 'eddy covariance system' mean in the context of measuring energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes?
Definition.Answer: An eddy covariance system is a measurement technique used to directly quantify the turbulent fluxes of energy, water vapor, and carbon dioxide between the surface and the atmosphere. It uses high-frequency data on wind speed and gas concentrations to calculate these fluxes, providing insights into the exchange processes occurring in ecosystems like the oasis–desert systems explored in the Heihe River Basin.

Comparison.Question: How does the data collection method using an eddy covariance system for turbulent fluxes compare to the meteorological observations collected with automatic weather stations in terms of frequency and types of data collected?
Comparison.Answer: The eddy covariance system collects turbulent flux data at a half-hourly frequency, focusing on energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes. In contrast, automatic weather stations collect hydrometeorological data, including radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, air temperature and humidity gradients, wind speed, and precipitation, with a 10-minute average period.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in the data quality control procedures between datasets collected from an eddy covariance system and those from a meteorological observation network?
Comparison.Answer: Both datasets undergo data processing and quality control procedures. The eddy covariance system data involves handling high-frequency turbulent flux measurements, while the meteorological network focuses on ensuring consistent data quality for various meteorological parameters. Common procedures include ensuring data completeness, removing duplicate records, and filtering out data that exceed physical or instrumental ranges.

Comparison.Question: In terms of spatial coverage and the types of environmental variables measured, how do the observational datasets from oasis–desert systems compare to those from an artificial oasis covered with maize, vegetables, and orchards?
Comparison.Answer: The oasis–desert system datasets cover a broader range of land surface flux and meteorological stations, monitoring long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, along with various hydrometeorological and soil parameters. The artificial oasis dataset specifically focuses on evapotranspiration and the ratios of soil and canopy components in a controlled agricultural environment, providing detailed measurements on specific dates.

Interpretation.Question: What are the implications of using different elevation levels for sensor placement in meteorological data collection, and how might this affect the interpretation of atmospheric data patterns?
Interpretation.Answer: The data collection method involves placing sensors at various elevation levels (5m, 7m, 10m, 15m, 20m, 28m) to capture wind speed, temperature, and humidity gradients. This approach helps in understanding vertical atmospheric profiles and variations in microclimates. The use of multiple sensor heights allows for a detailed analysis of atmospheric stability and turbulence, which is crucial for accurate meteorological modeling and interpretation of atmospheric data patterns.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of soil and canopy temperature data improve the accuracy of evapotranspiration models, and what challenges might arise from this data collection approach?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating soil and canopy temperature data enhances the accuracy of evapotranspiration models by providing detailed temperature profiles necessary for separating soil and canopy fluxes. The use of thermal infrared cameras for capturing these temperatures can help refine model inputs, leading to better estimation of evaporation and transpiration rates. Challenges may include classification errors in temperature data due to vegetation abundance and the need for accurate atmospheric correction in thermal measurements.

Interpretation.Question: What methodological considerations are important when ensuring data quality and completeness in long-term hydrometeorological datasets, and how might these affect the interpretation of ecosystem dynamics?
Interpretation.Answer: Ensuring data quality and completeness involves rigorous data processing and quality control procedures such as filling missing data, removing duplicates, and identifying outliers. This is crucial for maintaining the reliability of long-term hydrometeorological datasets. Accurate and complete datasets are essential for interpreting ecosystem dynamics, as they provide the foundation for identifying trends, understanding environmental changes, and making informed predictions about future conditions in oasis–desert ecosystems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it difficult to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems in arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Maintaining a balance between oasis and desert systems is difficult due to ecological degradation issues, such as drying rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These challenges are particularly pronounced in inland river basins of arid regions, which face significant environmental pressures.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes errors in the estimation of soil and canopy component temperatures using remote sensing techniques?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Errors in estimating soil and canopy component temperatures using remote sensing techniques can be caused by image classification errors, particularly in regions with varying vegetation abundance. Misclassification of soil and vegetation pixels can lead to overestimation of canopy temperature. Additionally, ignoring atmospheric radiation effects and uncertainties in radiation transmittance through the canopy can also contribute to estimation errors.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the consequences of using a high-resolution thermal camera for estimating component temperatures on the accuracy of evapotranspiration measurements?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a high-resolution thermal camera to estimate soil and canopy component temperatures can lead to better validation of evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration measurements. This method showed reliable estimates in latent heat fluxes and separated the latent fluxes of soil and vegetation components with reasonable accuracy when assessed against ground-based measurements.

Causal Consequence.Question: What impact does the use of stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes have on the validation of evapotranspiration models?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of stable oxygen and hydrogen isotopes allows for better validation of evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration estimates. This technique, combined with eddy covariance system measurements, provides a good prospect for improving two-source energy balance models by accurately estimating E/ET% and T/ET% ratios.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might long-term observational datasets affect the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Long-term observational datasets are crucial for achieving a quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems. They are indispensable for recognizing interactions within these systems and supporting ecological stability, socio-economic development, and sustainable oasis development.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it critical to establish a comprehensive hydrometeorological observation network in oasis–desert systems to support ecological stability and socioeconomic development?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals, and ensure the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of these exchanges is crucial to recognize oasis–desert interactions and protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases, necessitating long-term observations.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives of using high-resolution thermal cameras in combination with the TSEB model for estimating evapotranspiration in agricultural areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to estimate evaporation, transpiration, and evapotranspiration using soil and canopy component temperatures observed via a high-resolution thermal camera as inputs to a series TSEB model. This approach aims to better validate these estimates using a combination of stable oxygen and hydrogen isotope techniques and measurements from an eddy covariance system, especially in strongly advective irrigated agricultural areas.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of collecting long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in the oasis–desert systems using eddy covariance and scintillometer methods?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes, and auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. These datasets aim to provide a comprehensive understanding of the ecological interactions and support sustainable development in these regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are involved in ensuring data quality and control for hydrometeorological observations in an oasis–desert ecosystem?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedures for data quality and control in hydrometeorological observations include ensuring 144 data entries daily, marking missing data with -6999, removing duplicate records, deleting data that exceeds physical or instrument limits, marking questionable data in red, and standardizing date and time formats.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are soil and canopy component temperatures calculated and validated in evapotranspiration studies using thermal cameras?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Soil and canopy component temperatures are calculated using thermal images classified into soil and canopy pixels. Directional brightness temperatures are extracted and converted to radiation temperatures using incoming long-wave radiation and emissivities. Validation is done against radiometric temperatures calculated from observed incoming long-wave radiation.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instrumentation and methods are employed to measure turbulent fluxes and hydrometeorological data in arid oasis–desert areas?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Turbulent fluxes are measured using an eddy covariance system and scintillometer, while hydrometeorological data, including radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture, are observed from automatic weather stations averaging every 10 minutes.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the accurate measurement of soil and canopy component temperatures in heterogeneous landscapes?
Enablement.Answer: The use of a high-precision thermal infrared camera has enabled accurate measurement of soil and canopy component temperatures, which can be used as inputs for models like the TSEB to estimate evaporation and transpiration accurately.

Enablement.Question: How do remote sensing techniques enhance the data collection process in oasis–desert ecosystems for carbon and energy exchange studies?
Enablement.Answer: Remote sensing techniques, when combined with long-term field observations like eddy covariance systems and scintillometers, allow for detailed monitoring and analysis of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in oasis–desert ecosystems, enhancing the understanding of ecological interactions and carbon balance.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies support the integration of ground-based measurements with remote sensing data to improve the estimation of evapotranspiration over heterogeneous land surfaces?
Enablement.Answer: Integrating ground-based measurements, such as those from eddy covariance systems, with remote sensing data, facilitates the partitioning of evapotranspiration into its components using models like the TSEB. This method is supported by capturing soil and canopy component temperatures and validating the data against stable isotope techniques and energy balance equations.

Expectation.Question: Why might challenges arise in accurately estimating evapotranspiration in oasis-desert ecosystems using traditional data collection methods?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges may arise due to the heterogeneous nature of the surface, which includes a mixture of soil and vegetation with different temperatures and resistance to energy exchange. This complexity is compounded by the limitations in composite temperature separation, particularly in arid regions, and the uncertainties in measuring component temperatures and fluxes using traditional methods.

Expectation.Question: Why could there be difficulties in validating component temperatures derived from thermal infrared cameras in arid agricultural areas?
Expectation.Answer: Difficulties in validation could stem from errors in image classification, which vary with vegetation abundance and can lead to overestimation of canopy temperature. Additionally, ignoring atmospheric upwelling radiation and transmittance could introduce uncertainties in estimated temperatures, further complicating the validation of component temperatures in such environments.

Expectation.Question: Why might long-term observational datasets be crucial for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: Long-term observational datasets are critical because they provide comprehensive insights into the interactions between oasis and desert systems, which are essential for achieving sustainable development and ecological stability. They help recognize ecosystem interactions and support efforts towards ecological security and socioeconomic development in these regions.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the effectiveness of the data quality control procedures in hydrometeorological observations for ensuring reliable data collection?
Judgmental.Answer: The data quality control procedures in hydrometeorological observations appear to be comprehensive, as they include ensuring data completeness, removing duplicates, eliminating physically implausible or out-of-range data, marking questionable data, and standardizing date and time formats. These steps are crucial for maintaining data integrity and reliability, especially in long-term observational datasets.

Judgmental.Question: How would you judge the challenges faced in separating soil and canopy component temperatures using remote sensing techniques in heterogeneous landscapes?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges in separating soil and canopy component temperatures using remote sensing techniques in heterogeneous landscapes are significant, particularly due to classification errors in image pixels and uncertainties in estimating radiometric temperatures. These errors can impact the accuracy of temperature separation, which is crucial for models estimating evapotranspiration. The effectiveness of such techniques depends on the precision of the data inputs and the ability to account for complex interactions between soil and vegetation.

Judgmental.Question: What are your thoughts on the potential for integrating ground-based measurements and remote sensing data to improve dataset comprehensiveness in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating ground-based measurements with remote sensing data holds great potential for improving dataset comprehensiveness in oasis–desert ecosystems. Ground measurements provide detailed, localized data on energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, which can be complemented by the broader spatial coverage of remote sensing data. This integration can enhance the understanding of oasis–desert interactions and contribute to more accurate and scalable environmental monitoring and management.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand how meteorological data collection ensures accuracy when capturing such a wide variety of parameters like soil moisture, temperature, and radiation.
Assertion.Answer: Meteorological data collection in this field involves using a sophisticated network of sensors placed at various heights and locations, which capture detailed measurements for parameters like soil moisture, temperature, and radiation. Data processing includes quality control steps such as ensuring data completeness, removing duplicate records, and filtering out values beyond physical limits or instrument range to maintain accuracy.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how datasets from different locations within the Heihe River Basin can be integrated effectively for comprehensive analysis.
Assertion.Answer: Integration of datasets from different locations within the Heihe River Basin is facilitated by establishing a network of land surface flux and meteorological stations, providing consistent and comparable data over long-term periods. These datasets, including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, as well as auxiliary data, are processed and standardized for seamless integration and comprehensive analysis.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore different data collection methods for hydrometeorological observations in arid and semiarid regions and their associated challenges.
Request/Directive.Answer: In arid and semiarid regions, data collection methods for hydrometeorological observations typically involve the use of eddy covariance systems, automatic weather stations, and scintillometers. These methods gather data on turbulent fluxes, radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, and gradients of air temperature and humidity. A key challenge is ensuring data quality and accuracy, especially in environments like inland river basins where ecological degradation such as drying rivers and land desertification is taking place. Quality control procedures must address issues like data gaps, inaccuracies due to extreme conditions, and the need for long-term data to accurately understand oasis-desert interactions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and evaluate potential datasets for monitoring energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for monitoring energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis-desert ecosystems include long-term observational datasets from both artificial and natural systems. These datasets typically consist of energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane fluxes along with auxiliary data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. The study area in western China, for instance, has established 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations since 2012, providing a comprehensive dataset freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center. These datasets are crucial for understanding the interactions within oasis-desert ecosystems and for supporting sustainable development goals.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate the technological advancements and methodological approaches used to improve the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimation models in heterogeneous landscapes.
Request/Directive.Answer: Technological advancements and methodological approaches for improving the accuracy of evapotranspiration estimation models in heterogeneous landscapes include the use of the two-source energy balance (TSEB) model. This model has undergone revisions to enhance the estimation of soil and canopy net radiation, aerodynamic resistance, and component temperatures. Ground-based measurements such as soil and canopy component temperatures, captured using high-resolution thermal cameras, are integrated with the TSEB model to better estimate evapotranspiration. However, challenges remain in accurately separating component temperatures and dealing with errors due to image classification and strong advective environments. These advancements aim to improve model performance despite these challenges.
